summary: Directed evolution was used to expand the substrate scope of RebH, a tryptophan halogenase, allowing it to halogenate larger indoles and carbazoles. This enhances its utility for site-selective halogenation of biologically active compounds.
key_claims: Used directed evolution to expand the substrate scope of RebH
RebH variants can now halogenate tricyclic tryptoline derivatives and a broad range of large indoles and carbazoles

_refs.title: Note: we previously referred to 6-and 7-halogenation of tryptoline as 5and 6-halogenation, by analogy to the numbering used for L-tryptophan

_title: Directed Evolution of RebH for Site‚ÄêSelective Halogenation of Large Biologically Active Molecules
_abstract: We recently characterized the substrate scope of wild-type RebH and evolved variants of this enzyme with improved stability for biocatalysis. The substrate scopes of both RebH and the stabilized variants, however, are limited primarily to compounds similar in size to tryptophan. We have now used a substrate walking approach to further evolve RebH variants with expanded substrate scope. Two particularly notable variants were identified: 3-SS, which provides high conversion of tricyclic tryptoline derivatives; and 4-V, which accepts a broad range of large indoles and carbazoles. This constitutes the first reported use of directed evolution to enable functionalization of substrates not accepted by wild-type RebH and demonstrates the utility of RebH variants for site-selective halogenation of biologically active compounds.
